Introduction

Speaking up about any concern you have at work is really important. In fact, it's vital because it will help us to keep improving our services for all patients and the working environment for our staff. You may feel worried about raising a concern, and we understand this, but please don't be put off. In accordance with our duty of candour, our senior leaders and entire Board are committed to an open and honest culture. We will look into what you say and you will always have access to the support you need.

To have a standard integrated policy was one of a number of recommendations of the review by Sir Robert Francis into Whistleblowing in the NHS, aimed at improving the experience of whistleblowing in the NHS. This policy sets out the actions you can take to raise any concern and the action we will take in line with national best practice.

Speaking up about concerns supports Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (‘the Trust') in its commitment to achieve the highest possible standards of safe patient care and experience and creating a positive working environment for staff.

The Trust promotes a climate of openness and dialogue in which staff are encouraged to raise any concerns about potential risks, malpractices or wrongdoing, breaches of the law, regulations or similar concerns (“whistleblowing”) without fear of retaliation, which reflects the protections afforded by the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998. This Act offers legal protection against disadvantage (including victimisation, disciplinary/criminal action or dismissal) for members of staff who blow the whistle.
Examples of the relevant types of whistleblowing concerns include:
abuse of patients or unsafe practices
disregard of Trust policies and procedures
concerns about conduct or performance of colleagues which affects patient safety or care
breaches of codes of conduct
financial misconduct such as fraud or bribery (which can be reported to our local counter-fraud team, further details available on the Trust intranet site)
disregard of health and safety for patients, staff or the environment
deliberate attempt to conceal any of the above
a bullying culture (across a team or organisation rather than individual instances of bullying) – individual concerns should be raised in line with the Trust Bullying and Harassment at Work Policy.
Any concerns related to modern slavery/ trafficking and child forced labour.
For further examples, please see the Health Education England video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zjau1Ey0di8
Remember that if you are a healthcare professional you may have a professional duty to report a concern. If in doubt, please raise it!

Everyone has a duty, as set out in the NHS Constitution, to raise concerns about potential risks, malpractices or wrongdoing, breaches of the law, regulations or dangerous practice so as not to compromise patient safety, care or dignity. All staff have a duty to listen to patients, their carers and relatives, to be open with them and to contribute to a climate in which the truth can be heard and errors can be addressed and learned from. This is referred to as our “duty of openness, transparency and candour”. This policy provides guidance to support staff raise concerns and provide Trust's reassurance to staff that it is safe and acceptable to do so. The policy also ensures that any such concerns raised, are considered and addressed in an appropriate way, as early as possible.

Raising concerns is integral to the Trust values to ensure we promote a culture that is compassionate, respectful and promotes excellence to support a positive environment for our staff and patient care.
Scope

This policy and procedure should be used to raise any whistleblowing concerns described above. If you have a complaint about your personal situation, you should use the Grievance Policy and Procedure to raise their concern. Some examples of grievances, as distinguished from whistleblowing concerns, are set out below. The Grievance Policy and Procedure can be obtained from the Trust intranet page or from your line manager.

The purpose of this policy is to ensure that members of staff are aware of their duty of candour, openness and transparency, and to put in place a mechanism for them to raise concerns at work about potential risks, malpractices and wrongdoing, including breaches of the law or regulations. The policy also sets out the principles and procedures for ensuring concerns raised under this policy are dealt with, in a fair, timely and consistent manner.

This policy applies to all those who work for the Trust whether full-time, part-time, self-employed or employed through the bank or an agency. Other individuals performing functions in relation to the organisation, including sub-contractors and volunteers, are also encouraged to use it.

Some areas of existing practice carry a duty to report, for example where there are child protection issues. In addition, many codes of practice detail a professional duty to raise concerns. This policy builds on existing good practice and invites all staff to feel confident to raise concerns and be assured that they will be dealt with appropriately in accordance with the policy.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

Defined as raising a concern about a risk, malpractice or wrongdoing within an organisation. Examples might include ( but are not restricted to): abuse of patients or unsafe practices disregard of Trust policies and procedures concerns about conduct or performance of colleagues which affects patient safety or care breaches of codes of conduct financial misconduct such as fraud or bribery (which can be reported to our local counter- fraud team, further details available on the Trust intranet site) disregard of health and safety for patients, staff or the environment deliberate attempt to conceal any of the above a bullying culture (across a team or organisation rather than individual instances of bullying) – Any concerns related to modern slavery/ trafficking and child forced labour
All employees, both contracted and substantive, students and volunteers

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities
4.1.1 The Trust Executive team has overall responsibility for ensuring Whistleblowing cases are dealt with appropriately within the Trust.
4.1.2 The Trust Audit Committee has overall responsibility for reviewing the annual audit of the policy as delegated by the Executive Team.
4.1.3 The Trust Quality Committee is responsible for reporting on cases of whistleblowing, adherence to timescales, trends and lessons learned.

4.1.4 The People and Organisation and Development Committee is responsible for overseeing the Freedom to Speak Up strategy and progress with the agenda in line with the Trust and national requirements.
Individual responsibilities
4.2.1 All Staff

All staff have a duty of candour, openness and transparency under the NHS Constitution. This includes an obligation to raise genuine concerns as soon as reasonably practicable. Guidance for raising concerns is set out in Section
All staff have a duty to:
Maintain records and evidence relating to incidents and concerns forming the basis for raising concerns. This may include noting information such as the identities of other witnesses
Co-operate with any internal or external investigation
Treat staff fairly who raise concerns under this policy and procedure including not bullying, harassing or victimising these individuals.
4.2.2 Chief Executive

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring staff are able to raise concerns in accordance with the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998 and in accordance with the NHS Constitution and have a duty to:
Ensure that staff are not disadvantaged as a result of raising a genuine concern under this policy and procedure
Report to HR and the Executive lead any concerns raised under this policy
Ensure that the Trust responds formally to any concerns raised within the timescales in this policy.
4.2.3 Employee Relations
The Employee Relations Team has a duty to:
Monitor the effectiveness and application of the policy.
Maintain records for annual monitoring purposes.
Ensure that staff are not disadvantaged as a result of raising a genuine concern under the policy.
Ensure that all concerns raised under this policy are investigated and responded to formally within the timescales in this policy.
Determine the results and actions arising from an investigation completed under this policy and procedure.
4.2.4 All Directors, Managers and Lead Clinicians
All Directors, Managers and Lead Clinicians have a duty to:
Ensure that all staff are aware of this policy and procedure and have access to it.
Create a supportive and open working environment where staff feel encouraged to report any genuine concerns.
Ensure that members of staff are not disadvantaged as a result of raising a genuine concern under the policy.

Report to the lead Executive and Employee Relations Team any concerns raised under this policy and to ensure that all concerns are investigated and addressed in accordance with this policy and procedure for example, by appointing appropriate Commissioning Manager to manage the process.
4.2.5 Commissioning Manager
A commissioning manager will be appointed by the relevant Executive Director responsible for the case and has a duty to:
Where appropriate, appoint an investigating officer who is not from the same department and ensure that the investigation is undertaken fairly and independently within the timescales in this policy.
Report to the Executive Lead on receipt of the completed investigation, to determine what action should be taken.
Provide regular feedback to the individual raising the concern and to the Executive Lead and the Safeguarding Team if the case is also a safeguarding issue.
Maintain confidentiality and ensure that the Trust values are adhered to at all times.
4.2.6 Investigating Officer
An investigating officer will be appointed by the Commissioning Manager and has a duty to:

Ensure the investigation is conducted fairly and complete the investigation within the timescales in this policy and provide a completed report to the Commissioning Manager with recommendations (as appropriate).
Carry out the investigation objectively and produce a report that focuses on identifying and rectifying any issues and learning lessons to prevent problems recurring.
Provide regular feedback to the Commissioning Manager.
Maintain confidentiality and ensure that the Trust values are adhered to at all times.
4.2.7 Board of Directors

It is the responsibility of the Trusts Board of Directors to engender an open culture which invites and encourages both positive and negative feedback from all who use and work within the services. This feedback is used to inform future strategies to support an ethos of continual learning and improvement including the promotion of The Freedom to Speak Up Guardian as a central tenant of this culture.
4.2.8 Chief Executive and Chairman

The Chief Executive is responsible for appointing the Guardian and regularly meeting with them. They are also ultimately accountable for ensuring that The Guardian arrangements meet the needs of the staff members working in the Trust. The Chief Executive and Chairman are responsible for ensuring the Annual Report contains information from the Guardian on Freedom to Speak Up and confirms that the Trust is engaged with both the regional Guardian network, the National Guardian's Office and appropriately reports and benchmarks the Trust against national criteria to ensure a Freedom to Speak Up Culture is supported within the Trust, any issues identified and improvements are made to rectify the issue.
4.2.9 Executive Director responsible for Freedom to Speak Up
The Executive lead for Freedom to Speak Up is the Chief People and Organisational Development Director, who is responsible for:
Ensuring the Trust is aware of latest guidance from the National Guardian's Office
Overseeing the creation of the Freedom to Speak Up vision and strategy
Ensuring that the Guardian's role has been implemented, supported and has adequate cover to ensure staff can access as required.
Ensuring that a sample of speaking up cases have been quality assured
Conducting an annual review of the strategy, policy and process
Ensuring the learning derived from speaking up issues is embedded in the Trust's services
Ensuring allegations of detriment are promptly and fairly investigated and acted on
Providing the Board with a variety of assurance about the effectiveness of the Trust's strategy, policy and process
Ensuring meetings are held with the Guardian bi-monthly
4.2.10 Non-Executive Director responsible for Freedom to Speak Up

The Non-Executive Director (NED) lead is responsible for ensuring they are aware of latest guidance from National Guardian's Office and holding the Chief Executive, Executive Guardian lead and the Board to account for implementing the speaking up strategy.

Where necessary, the NED should robustly challenge the Board to reflect on whether it could do more to create a culture that is both responsive to feedback and focused on learning and continuous improvement across the entire organisation. They will:
Role-model high standards of conduct around Freedom to Speak Up
Act as an alternative source of advice and support for Freedom to Speak Up
Oversee any speaking up concerns regarding Board members
4.2.11 Chief Medical Officer and Chief Nursing Officer
The Chief Medical Officer and Chief Nursing Officer are responsible for:
Ensuring that the Guardian has appropriate support and advice on patient safety and safeguarding issues
Ensuring that effective and, as appropriate, immediate action is taken when potential patient safety issues are highlighted by speaking up
Ensuring learning is put into practice within the teams and departments they oversee
Principles

All members of staff have a duty to raise any concerns they have about patient safety, care or dignity or any breaches of health and safety, misconduct, fraud, bribery or malpractice at the Trust. This includes a duty to raise concerns in which members of staff are personally implicated or involved in the potential wrongdoing.

Members of staff need to feel safe to raise a concern under this policy. You will not be disadvantaged for raising a concern under this policy and procedure. This means that the continued employment and opportunities for future promotion or training will not be affected because you have raised a genuine concern. Members of staff should be watchful for illegal or unethical conduct or performance of any employee irrespective of role or seniority and raise anything of this nature that they become aware of. Matters raised under this policy and procedure will be investigated thoroughly, promptly and confidentially.

Staff can raise concerns anonymously, however this may make it difficult for the Trust to look into matters, so we would always encourage staff to share their concerns with someone appropriate they feel able to speak to so we can ensure we have all the information needed to look into the concerns, take appropriate action and ensure they are supported.

If misconduct is identified as a result of any investigation under this procedure the matter will be addressed under the Trust's disciplinary procedure, in addition to any appropriate external measures being taken.
The following conduct will be addressed under the Trust's disciplinary procedure:

Instructing a colleague to ‘cover up' or conceal a matter which would otherwise be raised under this policy and procedure. Any such attempt should, itself, be raised under this policy and procedure as a potential breach of the law, regulations and the duty of candour, openness and transparency;
Harassing, bullying or victimising a colleague because they have raised a concern under this policy and procedure (and in conjunction with the Trust Bullying and Harassment policy);
Deliberately making a false allegation under this policy and procedure.
Examples of Differences between a Grievance and a
Whistleblowing Concern
Line managers and lead clinicians should recognise that there is a difference between a grievance and a whistleblowing concern.
A grievance will relate to a member of staff personally. For example, the individual may have a complaint about:
their pay or working hours
the amount of work that they are expected to do
working conditions
being bullied by fellow workers

A whistleblowing concern, will relate to the conduct of another person in the workplace (whether or not that conduct affects the complainant personally), in circumstances where the complainant genuinely believes that the conduct in question amounts to potential risks, malpractices or wrongdoing, or potential breaches of the law or regulations.

Assurances to You

Your safety - The Trust is committed to this policy. If you raise a genuine concern under this policy, you will not be at risk of losing your job or suffer any form of disadvantage as a result, whether or not the concern is substantiated. The Trust does not extend this assurance to individuals who deliberately raise false concerns - the Trust may choose to discipline individuals in those circumstances.

Statutory protection- Under the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998 you are protected against disadvantage if you blow the whistle to the Trust or a nominated external body about a potential breach of the law, regulations or dangerous practice. Under the Act, it is unlawful for an employer to take disciplinary action, victimise or apply a disadvantage to a member of staff who raises a genuine concern.

Your confidence – Be assured that the Trust will not tolerate the harassment or victimisation of anyone raising a genuine concern. However, we recognise that you may nonetheless want to raise a concern in confidence under this policy. If you ask us to protect your identity we will, if possible, keep any reference to the concern or any subsequent investigation anonymous. However, we may be obliged to reveal your identity where investigation of serious allegations leads to the establishment of an external enquiry, police action against individuals or potential disciplinary action in relation to or dismissal of other members of staff. If it becomes clear that any of these situations may arise, we will discuss with you how to proceed.
Procedure – How to Raise a Concern Internally
The Employee Relations Team

The Employee Relations team are available to provide advice and support to staff who have concerns and are unsure about how to raise them. Employees can raise issues by writing confidentially to the Head of Employee Relations or a member of the team via mse.smtemployee.relations@nhs.net
Freedom to Speak up Champions

Across the Trust, there are Freedom to Speak Up Champions. These are colleagues in all divisions who are available to provide advice and support to staff who have concerns and are unsure about how to raise them. Speak up Champions are staff working in the Trust, who have a genuine interest in helping the Trust to listen to concerns of colleagues.
Union Representatives
Staff also can access support from their Union representatives, where they feel they need more formal representation or you may invite your union or professional body to raise matters on your behalf.
Freedom to Speak Up Guardian

This is an important role identified in the Freedom to Speak Up review to act as an independent and impartial source of advice to staff at any stage of raising a concern. The Trust contracts an external service to provide the Freedom to Speak Up Guardian role. The Guardian Service can be contacted by phone or email 24/7. They offer an independent, strictly confidential, non-judgemental, and supportive staff liaison service and can be contacted by:
Tel: 0333 001 5125 (Southend)
Tel: 0333 230 9299 (Basildon)
Tel: 0333 577 5799 (Broomfield)
Email: contact@theguardianservice.co.uk
The above sources of support can be contacted at any stage in the process detailed below to offer advice and support with raising and resolving a concern.
Raising a concern Step one

8.1.1 If you have a concern, if able you should raise it firstly with your immediate line manager or lead clinician. You should raise it verbally first and you may be asked to describe your concerns in writing at a later date.
Step two

8.1.2 If you feel unable to raise the matter with your immediate line manager or lead clinician, for whatever reason, or you feel that the line manager or lead clinician has failed to undertake a proper investigation you can raise your concern by using any of the options in section 8 or by submitting your concerns via email to: The Head of Employee Relations via mse.smtemployee.relations@nhs.net.

8.1.3 Where abuse of a patient has occurred or thought to have occurred, or if a patient (or patients) is put at risk by the behaviour or neglect of a member of staff the relevant Safeguarding Team must be informed as soon as possible.
Step three

8.1.4 If the above channels have been followed and you still have concerns, or if you feel that the matter is so serious that you cannot discuss it with any of the individuals listed above, you should raise your concern to the Executive Lead for Freedom to Speak Up or Chief Executive who will decide on how the matter should be taken forward and will be responsible for nominating a commissioning manager based on the nature of the concern raised. The Freedom to Speak Up, Non-Executive Guardian Lead can also be contacted.

8.1.5 Matters raised in relation to patient safety, safeguarding or quality of service will be referred to the Chief Medical Officer or Chief Nursing Officer Executive Lead and they will be responsible for nominating a commissioning manager to take the matter forward.

8.1.6 Matters raised in relation to fraud, bribery and/ or corruption will be referred to the Chief Financial Officer Executive lead and they will be responsible for nominating the Trust's Local Counter Fraud Specialist to undertake an investigation on their behalf.
You can contact a Speak up Champion, the Freedom to Speak Up Guardian and trade union representatives for advice and / or support at any stage during the above process

8.1.7 The Trust recognises its accountability within the NHS. In light of this, should you consider that your concern has not been addressed internally then you can also contact the organisations set out in this policy (raising your concern with an outside body). You will be protected against disadvantage under the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998 if you make any disclosures to the Care Quality Commission or Monitor.

8.1.8 You can also contact the Whistleblowing Helpline for the NHS and social care, your professional body or trade union representative. Further information is detailed in the External contacts section of this policy.
How should I raise my concern?

You can raise your concern in accordance with this policy with any people listed above in person, by phone or in writing. Whichever route you choose, please provide as much information as possible relating to the circumstances that gives rise to this concern.

The Trust recognises that the decision to report a concern can be difficult one to make, not least because of the fear of reaction from those responsible for the malpractice. The Trust will not tolerate harassment or victimisation and will take action to protect you when you raise a concern.
How we will handle the matter

The Trust is committed to the principles of the Freedom to Speak Up review and its vision for raising concerns, and will respond in line with them. See ‘our vision for raising concerns' in the appendix section of this policy.

If the member of staff has been unable to raise the concern informally, or does not feel that from following informal interventions the issues have been resolved, they can raise the concern in line with section 8 of this policy.

The person to whom the concern was raised will report it to the Head of Employee Relations, who will determine if it falls within the definition of a ‘qualifying disclosure' under the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998. See section below on protected disclosures.

The Head of Employee Relations will ensure that the concern is logged on the central record log, which will include the date the concern was received, a summary of the concerns and dates of actions in relation to the case. They will advise on the policy and the appointment of a commissioning manager.
The matter will be acknowledged within 7 calendar days by the commissioning manager.

The commissioning manager will meet with the staff member that raised the concern to identify and agree the appropriate action/process to be taken. They will discuss your concerns with you to ensure we understand exactly what you are worried about.

The commissioning manager will appoint an investigating officer where appropriate. This will be someone suitably independent and appropriately trained who will be in a position to reach a conclusion within a reasonable timeframe. The investigation will be objective and evidence based and will produce a report that focuses on identifying and rectifying any issues, and learning lessons to prevent problems recurring.

The investigation will be completed within 30 calendar days, except where an extension is agreed by the commissioning manager. Cases can be complex and it is important that the issues are given due consideration. We will therefore tell you how long we expect the investigation to take and keep you updated.

Staff members raising concerns may be required to provide a statement in relation to their concerns. Appropriate support will be offered to staff throughout the process (see section 11 below on support available).
The member of staff raising the concern will be updated by the commissioning manager throughout the process at least every 2 weeks.

The outcome of the investigation will be a report which will be provided to the commissioning manager. We will share the report with you, wherever possible (while respecting the confidentiality of others).
The commissioning manager will then report back to the Executive Lead who will determine what action should be taken.

The Commissioning Manager will write to the staff member raising the concerns, or meet with them to confirm the outcome of the investigation and what action the Trust proposes to take to address any issues identified. Please note, however, that the Trust may not be able to disclose the precise action the Trust takes where this would infringe a duty of confidence owed by us to someone else, particularly if the Trust or professional body has taken formal disciplinary action. If no action is to be taken, the reason for this will be explained by the commissioning manager, if appropriate. This will be followed up in a formal letter confirming the discussion.
Everyone who raises a concern will be thanked for doing so, providing they have not done so, anonymously.
The Commissioning Manager will ensure that an action plan is put in place based on any matters arising from investigation to address learning.
How we will learn from your concern

The focus of the investigation will be on improving the service we provide. Where it identifies improvements that can be made the relevant director for the area of concerns will ensure an action plan is in place and will track them to ensure necessary changes are made and we are working effectively. The Executive Director will also ensure lessons are shared with teams across the organisation, more widely, as appropriate. Where appropriate, organisational learning will be shared through team brief, wider staff newsletters and staff forums.

The Board will be given high level anonymised information about all concerns raised by our staff through this policy and what we are doing to address problems. High level information will be provided in our annual report to the Board.

The Freedom to Speak Up Guardian will also meet with the Executive and Non- Executive lead throughout the year to provide feedback on concerns being raised and trends to ensure these continue to be monitored and under review.
We will review the effectiveness of this policy and local processes at least annually, with the outcome published and changes made appropriate.
Support for Independent Advice for Workers
Raising a concern can be stressful and the Trust want to ensure that you feel supported throughout this process. There are a variety of sources of support available to Trust staff, including:
Occupational Health

Occupational Health provides a confidential counselling service for those members of staff who have a problem that is affecting their work and personal life. In certain circumstances where more specialised counselling is required, they will recommend an agency for the employee to contact directly. Staff may either be referred to Occupational Health by their manager (with consent) or may refer themselves confidentially. Further information is available on the Trust Intranet or staff can contact Occupational Health by telephone through the hospital switchboard.
Health and Wellbeing Support

The Trust promotes mental health and wellbeing and in line with this provides extensive support to staff through ‘Healthy Me' MSE publications. Services provided can be accessed from the Trusts staff intranet pages.
Freedom to Speak up Champions
Staff can access the support of Freedom to Speak Up Champions as detailed previously in this policy.
Further information, including an up to date list of the Trust champions can be accessed from the Freedom to Speak Up section of our Staff intranet page.
Freedom to Speak up Guardian
Staff can access the support of Freedom to Speak Up Guardians as detailed previously in this policy.
Further information is available under the Freedom to Speak Up section of the Staff intranet page.
Employee Relations
Staff can access advice and support in relation to raising concerns under this policy from the Employee Relations team.
Each Division has an Employee relations lead who can be contacted or you can email mse.smtemployee.relations@nhs.net.
Staffside/ Union Representation
Staff can access advice and representation for raising a concern from their Trade Union representative.
Trade Unions also provide members with health and wellbeing support. For further information please contact you union or Staffside chair. Contact details are posted on the Staff intranet.
If you are dissatisfied

If you are unhappy with the response, remember you can go to the other levels and bodies detailed in this policy. While we cannot guarantee that we will provide the outcome you seek in every case, we will handle the matter fairly and responsibly. By using this policy, you will help us to achieve this.
External Contacts

If you are unsure whether to use this procedure or you want independent advice at any stage, you may contact a Speak up Champion, a local trade union representative or the independent charity Public Concern at Work (PCaW) on 020 7404 6609 or by email whistle@pcaw.org.uk .

Public Concern at Work (PCaW) is the independent authority on public interest whistleblowing. Established as a charity in 1993, PCaW has played a leading role in putting whistleblowing on the governance agenda and in developing legislation in the UK and abroad. They provide free advice to people with whistleblowing queries. Their lawyers can give you free confidential advice at any stage about how to raise a concern about serious malpractice at work.

Alternatively the government funded National Whistleblowing free phone help line can give independent and confidential advice to NHS staff. Their telephone number is 08000 724 725 or they can be contacted by email on www.wbhelpline.org.uk.

While we hope this policy gives you the reassurance you need to raise such matters internally with us, we would rather you raise a matter with the appropriate regulator, than not at all. Public Concern at Work will be able to advise you on such an option and on the circumstances, in which you may be able to contact an outside body safely such as the Care Quality Commission, Monitor, NHS Protect or the Audit Commission (details of which are set out at appendix 1).
Raising your concern with an outside body
Alternatively, you can raise your concern outside the organisation with: NHS Improvement for concerns about:
how NHS trusts and foundation trusts are being run
other providers with an NHS provider licence
NHS procurement, choice and competition
the national tariff
Care Quality Commission for quality and safety concerns http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/report-concern-if-you-are-member-staff
NHS England https://www.england.nhs.uk/contact-us/ for concerns about:
primary medical services (general practice)
primary dental services
primary ophthalmic services
local pharmaceutical services
Health Education England for education and training in the NHS. https://www.hee.nhs.uk/about/contact-us-0
NHS Protect for concerns about fraud and corruption. http://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/3350.aspx
Making a ‘protected disclosure'

There are very specific criteria that need to be met for an individual to be covered by whistleblowing law when they raise a concern (to be able to claim the protection that accompanies it). There is also a defined list of ‘prescribed persons', similar to the list of outside bodies in 3.6, who you can make a protected disclosure to. To help you consider whether you might meet these criteria, please seek advice from your Trade Union or Professional Organisation, the Whistleblowing Helpline for the NHS and social care, Public Concern at Work or a legal representative.
National Freedom to Speak Up Guardian

The National Guardian can independently review how staff have been treated having raised concerns where NHS trusts and foundation trusts may have failed to follow good practice, working with some of the bodies listed above to take action where needed.
Training requirements
All managers who have responsibility for staff should attend appropriate courses organised by the Human Resources Department.
No specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the HR Policy Working Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It  is  the  author's  responsibility  to  inform  the  HR  Policy Working  Group  of  the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Appendix 2: Process for raising and escalating a concern (quick reference guide)

table_items.text: Process for raising and escalating a concern (a quick reference guide)

Step one If you have a concern about a risk, malpractice or wrongdoing at work, we hope you will feel able to raise it first with your line manager or lead clinician. This may be done orally or in writing. You may invite your union or professional body to raise the matter on your behalf. When a meeting is arranged, you have a right to be accompanied by a member of a recognised negotiating body of the Trust or a work colleague. Step two If you feel unable to raise the matter with your line manager or lead clinician, for whatever reason, you or your representative should raise the matter with: Our local Freedom to Speak Up Guardian(s), provided by the Guardian Service: Tel: 0333 001 5125 (Southend) Tel: 0333 230 9299 (Basildon) Tel: 0333 577 5799 (Broomfield) Email: contact@theguardianservice.co.uk Freedom to Speak Up Champions: These are colleagues who have been given special responsibility and training in dealing with raising concerns and will support and sign post you so you can raise your concern. Full details of nominated champions are available on the Trust Intranet site. Employee Relations: If you feel unable to raise the matter with your immediate line manager or lead clinician, for whatever reason, or you feel that the line manager or lead clinician has failed to undertake a proper investigation you can raise your concerns via email to: The Head of Employee Relations via mse.smtemployee.relations@nhs.net. The Employee Relations team also can provide you with further advice and guidance in line with this this policy. The above avenue of support with ensure: All workers whose identity is known will be thanked for raising the concern. treat your concern confidentially unless otherwise agreed ensure you receive timely support to progress your concern escalate to the board any indications that you are being subjected to detriment for raising your concern remind the organisation of the need to give you timely feedback on how your concern is being dealt with ensure you have access to personal support since raising your concern may be stressful.

data.text: If you want to raise the matter in confidence, please say so at the outset so that appropriate arrangements can be made.
Step three
If these channels have been followed and you still have concerns, or if you feel that the matter is so serious that you cannot discuss it with any of the above, please contact:
our Executive Director with responsibility for raising concerns Danny Hariram or our Chief Executive Clare Panniker.
or
our Non-Executive director with responsibility for Freedom to Speak Up and raising concerns, Deepak Singh

If you have any concerns throughout the process and stages, please contact the Freedom to Speak Up Guardian(s), provided by the Guardian Service who will support facilitate the process (contact details confirmed above).
Step four
You can raise concerns formally with external bodies – see this webpage for the full list: List of prescribed bodies. http://fcsp.xfyldecoast.nhs.uk/F/FTSU/Pages/default.aspx
